column2: Publicly Backs Polievre in Canadian Media Campaign
column3:
Morgan, along with dozens of other Canadian CEO's, publicly backed Pierre Poilievre with paid advertising in Canadian media during the 2025 Canadian election.

A total of $350,000 was spent on these ads, according to campaign filings, with more than half of it going to Postmedia, the company that owns the National Post.

column2: Overlap Between Poilievre Ad Signers and Canada Proud Donors
column3:
Gwyn Morgan is not the only person who signed the pro-Poilievre advertisement and also donated to political campaign front groups.

Peter Gilgan, CEO of Mattamy Homes, signed the advertisement supporting Pierre Poilievre in the 2025 Canadian election. Mattamy Homes donated $100,000 to Ontario Proud in 2018 in support of Doug Ford, on top of direct donations to the Ontario Progressive Conservative party.

column2: How This Is Connected to Oil & Gas
column3:
Many of the signers of the pro-Poilievre ad are executives for oil companies. Canadian oil and gas companies and their CEO's have been pushing for increased oil & gas production in Canada.

Poilievre's own statements have been largely in support of investing in Canadian oil infrastructure, including for new pipelines.

Imperial, a key member of Pathways Alliance, has donated to the Fraser Institute and the Macdonald-Laurier Institute, both Atlas Network partners.

Canada's big four oil companies — Canadian Natural Resources, Cenovus, Imperial Oil and Suncor — are four of the five companies behind Pathways Alliance, who has advanced a plan to reduce oil sands emissions through carbon capture technology. 

Despite the fact that this technology has never been implemented anywhere in the world, the industry is advancing these potential emissions reductions as a justification for increased oil and gas production.

On top of this, Pathways has requested that Canadian tax payers pay for more than half of the cost of building the carbon capture infrastructure.
